description.p: Flicking her wrist and watching her tattoos turns a bright blue, the tiefling turns to look at her assailant. A man dressed in dark leathers with a cowl over his head watches her as he slowly pulls a knife from his belt. The tiefling scowls as ice begins to cover her skin, and then makes a motion with her hands as ice begins to rain down from above. The man ducks to the side, narrowly avoiding the ice, and lunges towards the woman, but his knife doesn’t managed to slip through the armour of ice that now shields her. She laughs and her tattoos glow again, now a bright yellow. She makes a motion to back hand him and there’s a spark of lightning and a clap of thunder as he’s thrown down the alley. He groans and goes to find his dagger, but the woman places her boot on his chest, her tattoos now a fiery red. The man begins to scream, but his tongue turns to ash fire swirls around the tiefling, scorching the man and the alley.

This woman is a conduit, a person artificially infused with and fuelled by magic. While similar to sorcerers, a conduit isn’t skilled enough to hone their magic into spell slots, and instead unleashes their arcane firepower in destructive bursts.

All conduits were once non-magical people. They had next to no natural ability with magic, and even if they could pull off a cantrip, they were unable to grasp the concepts and theory required to learn magic like a wizard would. Instead, these people were infused with magic, which now flows through their veins, sustaining them and allowing them to unleash destruction on their foes.

Either by rituals, experimentation, or planar forces, the bodies of conduits have been twisted and re-defined by the magic they now wield. Some conduits are created during wars, so that armies have arcane firepower that can be counted on to burn itself out before managing to flee. Others are accidents gone wrong, and might be caught in a dangerous spell, and have the magic flood their being.

Conduits are able to manipulate prime elemental forces. With destructive control over fire, ice, and lightning, they can tear apart their opposition. Each of these elements manifest in the same way among all conduits, but some favour one element over another, and other conduits might refuse to use a certain element all together.

The first thing you should consider when creating your conduit character is how you acquired your magic. Were you branded with powerful runes, did you fall into a devastating arcane trap, or even fall victim to the magic of creatures from the outer planes?

Regardless of how you got your magic, you should also consider how it manifests. Does your character have tattoos on their body that glow when they use their magic, or does the air around them shimmer with energy as they use their surges?

Finally, consider how your character feels about their new power. Do they relish in it, and enjoy the power that now courses through their body, or do they fear it, and struggle to control their magic when their emotions get the better of them?
You can make a conduit quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Intelligence, followed by Dexterity or Constitution. Second, choose the hermit background.
As an conduit, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per conduit level after 1st
Skills: hoose two from Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, Perception, and Religion

description.p: Alternatively, you may start with 2d4 × 10 gp to buy your own equipment.

description.p: Starting at 1st level, you can begin to manipulate the very fabric of magic, allowing you access to magical powers and abilities which you can spend potential energy to use and enhance: surges and focuses. Surges are raw power in arcane form, which can devastate the battlefield. Focuses shape your surges and allow you to hone your abilities.

You have an amount of potential energy equal to your Intelligence modifier + your conduit level (rounded up). You regain all your spent potential energy when you finish a long rest, and half your total amount of potential energy when you finish a short rest.
You know two surges when you first gain this feature, which are detailed below. You learn an additional surge at 5th level, and one more at 11th level.

You know two focuses when you first gain this feature, which are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain conduit levels, you gain additional focuses of your choice, as shown in the Focuses Known column of the Conduit table. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the focuses you know and replace it with another focus.

Whenever you use a surge on your turn, you can choose a single focus, spending an amount of potential energy specified by it, to add an additional affect to that surge. Whenever you use a focus on the Arcane Bolt surge, the potential you have to spend to use that focus is reduced by 1 (this doesn’t effect potential spent to overcharge a focus).
Once you use a focus, you can’t use that focus again until the start of your next turn.

Some surges and focuses can be overcharged, allowing you to spend additional potential to enhance their effects. You can spend any number of potential on an overcharge, up to a maximum number equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) on any overcharge.

Some of your surges and focuses require you to make an attack roll, or require the target to make a saving throw to resist the talent’s effects. Your attack modifier and the saving throw DC are calculated as follows:
Arsenal Save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Arsenal attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

Whenever you use a surge on your turn, you can choose a single focus, spending an amount of potential energy specified by it, to add an additional affect to that surge. You can spend up to {{arsenal:overcharge-limit}} potential energy to overcharge surges and focuses.

Overcharge. Each additional 1 point you spend increases the length of the area by 10 feet.

description.p: Also at 1st level, the magic that bubbles inside you grants you innate arcane powers and unique insight. You learn the prestidigitation cantrip, and the total number of its non-instantaneous effects you can have at once is increased by an amount equal to your Intelligence modifier.
Additionally, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) to any Intelligence check that doesn’t already include your proficiency bonus.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, you can attune yourself to the elements that exist within the world; fire, ice, and lightning, enhancing and altering your magical capabilities, which are detailed at the end of the class description. Each affinity grants features at 2nd level, and additional features at 7th, 10th, and 14th level.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can shift your affinity, granting you access to different abilities and features. You can’t use your bonus action to shift to an affinity you’re currently shifted to. Each affinity has a relevant damage type and changes the type of saving throw associated with your surges, detailed below. While attuned to an affinity, you can have your surges deal that affinities relevant damage type. You can end your attunement to an affinity at any time during your turn, no action required.

When you gain the Elemental Affinity feature, you choose three affinities from the available options. You can only shift between your chosen affinities, and can’t access any other affinities. Additional affinities can be found linked in the credits section, at the end of the class description.

sheet.description: You can shift between your chosen affinities. You can end your attunement to an affinity at any time during your turn, no action required.

description.p: At 2nd level, when you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for a surge you use while attuned to any affinity, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the roll is a 1 or 2. If the damage type of the surge doesn’t match your affinities damage type, you can’t reroll a die this way.

sheet.description: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for a surge you use while attuned to any affinity, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the roll is a 1 or 2. If the damage type of the surge doesn’t match your affinities damage type, you can’t reroll a die this way.

description.p: At 3rd level, the arcane energy in your body lets you surge into battle. You gain a bonus to your initiative checks equal to your Intelligence modifier.

Also at 3rd level, you gain a deeper insight into arcane magic. You can spend 1 potential energy to cast either detect magic or identify without requiring material components. When you go to cast identify this way, you can spend 1 additional potential energy to reduce its casting time to 1 action.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 potential energy to cast either detect magic or identify without requiring material components. When you go to cast identify this way, you can spend 1 additional potential energy to reduce its casting time to 1 action.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
At 5th level, when you use a surge as an action on your turn, you can perform a second surge as part of that action. You can’t perform the same surge more than once as part of this action.
The number of surges you perform increases to three at 11th level and four at 20th level.

sheet.description: When you use a surge as an action on your turn, you can perform a {{destructive-surge:uses}} surge as part of that action. You can’t perform the same surge more than once as part of this action.

description.p: Also at 5th level, when a creature succeeds on a saving throw against your surges, the creature takes half the surge’s damage. Additionally, when you miss a creature you can see with a surge attack roll, you can have the creature take force damage equal to your Intelligence modifier.

sheet.description: When a creature succeeds on a saving throw against your surges, the creature takes half the surge’s damage. Additionally, when you miss a creature you can see with a surge attack roll, you can have the creature take {{intelligence:modifier}} force damage.

description.p: At 6th level, the magic inside of you fuels your body, granting you the following benefits:

ul.li: You no longer need to eat or drink.
You no longer need to sleep and can’t be forced to sleep by any means. To gain the benefits of a long rest, you can spend 8 hours doing light activity, such as reading a book or keeping watch.

sheet.description: You no longer need to eat or drink. You no longer need to sleep and can’t be forced to sleep by any means. To gain the benefits of a long rest, you can spend 8 hours doing light activity, such as reading a book or keeping watch.

description.p: Starting at 9th level, you can channel your magic to ascend to new heights. When you perform a surge as an action on your turn, you can spend 3 potential energy to gain a flying speed of 20 feet until the end of your next turn. If you spend potential energy to overcharge a surge or use a focus, or use one of your subclass features, you only need to spend 1 potential energy to gain this flying speed.

sheet.description: When you perform a surge as an action on your turn, you can spend 3 potential energy to gain a flying speed of 20 feet until the end of your next turn. If you spend potential energy to overcharge a surge or use a focus, or use one of your subclass features, you only need to spend 1 potential energy to gain this flying speed.

description.p: Starting at 13th level, your body transcends mortal needs as your very soul radiates magical power. You gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You no longer need to breathe.
You no longer age, can’t die of old age, and can’t be aged by magical means.
Your ability scores can’t be reduced.

sheet.description: You no longer need to breathe. You no longer age, can’t die of old age, and can’t be aged by magical means. Your ability scores can’t be reduced.

description.p: At 15th level, you can unleash your arcane potential. When you perform a surge as an action on your turn, you can spend 1 potential energy. If you do so, you’re able to perform the same surge more than once as part of your Destructive Surge feature.

sheet.description: When you perform a surge as an action on your turn, you can spend 1 potential energy. If you do so, you’re able to perform the same surge more than once as part of your Destructive Surge feature.

description.p: At 17th level, you’re able to truly ascend above others. You don’t need to spend any potential energy to gain a flying speed from your Rising Power feature as long as you’ve spent potential to overcharge a surge or use a focus, or used one of your affinity features during your turn.

sheet.description: You don’t need to spend any potential energy to gain a flying speed from your Rising Power feature as long as you’ve spent potential to overcharge a surge or use a focus, or used one of your affinity features during your turn.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, you can channel all your destructive elemental power into one destructive flurry. When you use your action to surge on your turn, you can choose to unleash this power. Until the end of your turn, each of your surges deals its damage three times to any creature that it hits or is in its area.
Once you use this feature, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you use your action to surge on your turn, you can choose to unleash this power. Until the end of your turn, each of your surges deals its damage three times to any creature that it hits or is in its area.

description.p: When you hit a creature or it fails its saving throw against one of your surges, you can spend 2 potential energy to reduce its movement speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.
Overcharge. Each additional 1 potential you spend decreases a creature’s speed by an additional 5 feet.

Overcharge. You can spend an additional 1 potential to daze them further. If the creature hits with the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn, you can reduce the damage it deals by an amount equal to your Intelligence modifier.

description.p: While attuned to ice, you’re able to better resist the strength of your foes, and can reach out to ensnare them. Compared to fire and lightning, ice can feel sluggish, but conduits know that the chill of winter is just as powerful as a raging storm or a blazing inferno.

sheet.description: Damage Type: Cold. Saving Throw: Constitution

description.p: At 2nd level, you can channel the glacial power of the arctic. When you shift to this affinity, you gain temporary hit points equal to 1d4 + half your conduit level, which last until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you shift to this affinity, you gain 1d4 + {{level:conduit:half}} temporary hit points, which last until the start of your next turn.

description.p: At 7th level, your ice grips those who defy you. When you hit a creature with a surge or it fails its saving throw against one, you can have that creature become restrained until the start of your next turn, as ice begins to cover it. When it breaks free, it takes 2d8 cold damage, as the ice shatters.
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 7th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a short rest.

Once you use this feature, or any of your other 7th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

description.p: At 10th level, you can shrug off even the most chilling effects. You are resistant to cold damage, and have advantage on ability checks and saving throws to avoid being knocked prone, grappled, or restrained.

description.p: At 14th level, you can encase yourself or another creature in ice. As an action on your turn, you can choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. That creature must make a Constitution saving throw or take 4d12 cold damage and becomes petrified in ice until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn’t petrified. Each creature of your choice within 30 feet of the target takes 2d12 cold damage.
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 14th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

description.p: At 2nd level, you can channel the blazing power of the inferno. While shifted to this affinity, you can reduce your foes to ash. When you deal fire damage to a creature with a conduit ability, and the damage reduces that creature to a number of hit points equal to or below your conduit level, it dies and turns to ash.

sheet.description: While shifted to this affinity, when you deal fire damage to a creature with a conduit ability, and the damage reduces that creature to {{level:conduit}} hit points or below, it dies and turns to ash.

description.p: At 7th level, your fire sears those who would oppose you. When you hit a creature with a surge or it fails its saving throw against one, you can have that creature become wreathed in magical fire until the start of your next turn. While covered in this fire, any time a creature other than yourself deals damage to it, it takes an additional 1d4 fire damage.
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 7th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

That creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking fire damage equal to 20d4 + your Conduit level on a failed save, and half as much on a success. If this damage reduces the creature to 0 hit points, it explodes, and each creature within 10 feet of it takes fire damage equal to 5d4 + your Conduit level.
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 14th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: Damage Type: Lightning. Saving Throw: Dexterity

description.p: At 2nd level, you can channel the energizing power of the storm. While shifted to this affinity, your speed increases by 10 feet and opportunity attacks against you have disadvantage.

When a creature fails its saving throw against one of your surges, you can have that creature take an additional 1d6 lightning damage for each other creature in the surge’s area, up to a maximum number of extra d6 equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 7th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You are resistant to lightning damage, and have advantage on ability checks and saving throws to avoid being paralyzed.

description.p: At 14th level, you can surge across the battlefield light a bolt of lightning. As an action on your turn, you can move up to four times your speed without provoking attacks of opportunity. You can move through creatures while moving this way, and the first time you move through a creature, it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 8d6 lightning damage, and takes half as much damage on a success.
Once you use this feature, or any of your other 14th level Affinity features, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

The wall of earth is Medium, has 13 AC and provides half cover to creatures behind it. After the wall provides cover from an attack, is hit by an attack, or at the end of your next turn, it crumbles and vanishes.
